Award.AwardTitle: Journey to the Center of the Earth: REVEALing a Subterranean Landscape of Fear in the North Atlantic
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks EAGER funding to test REVEAL, a new 3-dimensional mapping and site documentation product developed by Brown University's School of Engineering, in the challenging subterranean environment of Surtshellir, (Surtur's cave), a unique archaeological site in the North. Surtshellir was named by medieval Icelanders for the fire-giant that Viking Age Norse colonists believed would bring about the destruction of the world. Medieval texts describe Viking Age chieftains traveling to propitiate this fire-giant in Surtshellir and, later, to defeat outlaws said to have taken refuge in the cave. Thirteenth century sources describe brutal political acts of mutilation and revenge carried out by chieftains inside this cave during the 1240s. These and other references suggest that Surtshellir may have beenthe most feared place in Iceland, but also a location linked to acts of social restoration by medieval Iceland?s chieftains. Understanding this unique site therefore has the potential to provide new insights into the sacred and social roles of leaders within Iceland?s complex indigenous society.

Preliminary work inside Surtshellir in 2001 documented that it contains (1) one of the best-preserved Viking Age structures in the world, (2) a massive dry-stone wall, and (3) a pile of domestic animal bones, crushed, chopped, burned and thrown from the structure deeper into the cave. All are located deep within this, Iceland's longest lava cave. Now, we intend to use REVEAL to gain new information on the unique deposits inside Surtshellir and to use this opportunity to test REVEAL's ability to document archaeological features within the logistically challenging environments of subterranean and interior spaces, where it may be able to make its greatest contributions. Further, as the archaeological remains in Surtshellir cave are actively endangered through unregulated tourism and are threatened by the inevitable collapse of the cave in which they are located, this project will provide critical documentation and tools for the site's protection and long-term management by the Icelandic Archaeological Heritage Agency (Fornleifavernd Ríkisins) and the National Museum of Iceland (Þjóðminjasafn Íslands), both of which are partners in this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal sought EAGER funding to test REVEAL, a new 3-dimensional mapping and site documentation product developed by Brown University’s School of Engineering in the challenging subterranean environment of Surtshellir (Surtur’s cave).

Surtshellir is one of Iceland's longest lava caves, which formed during the course of a massive eruption underway when Norse settlers first arrived in Iceland from Scandinavia and the British Isles at the end of the 9th century AD. The cave was named "Surtshellir" by medieval Icelanders for the being, Surtur, who Viking Age Norse colonists believed would bring about the death of the gods and the destruction of the world by fire at Ragnarök, the "twilight of the gods". Medieval texts briefly describe a Viking Age chieftain traveling to propitiate this fire-giant in Surtshellir, while later stories suggest that a coalition of chieftains formed to defeat a band of outlaws who had taken refuge in the cave. Other sources describe brutal acts of mutilation in the cave, as well as spirits and ghosts who killed those who entered it. Surtshellir may have been the most feared place in Iceland, yet its records inevitably also link the cave to acts of social restoration by medieval Iceland’s chieftains. Understanding this unique site therefore suggested high potential for providing new insights into the sacred and social roles of leaders within Iceland’s complex indigenous medieval society.

In 2012, we used REVEAL to gain new information on the unique deposits inside Surtshellir and to test REVEAL’s ability to document archaeological features in challenging subterranean environments. We also used REVEAL to provide critical information and tools for the site’s protection and long-term management by the Icelandic Archaeological Heritage Agency and the National Museum of Iceland, both of which were partners in this research.

This project completely changed our understanding of Surtshellir's archaeological record. In 2001, we thought the site's remains fit reasonably with the view that the cave was an outlaw band's base. Work done in 2012 demolished this hypothesis. Massive bone piles representing the remains of hundreds of domestic animals are present in the cave, but with no evidence they were processed for utilitarian consumption, neither fuel for cooking nor ash from fires. There are no areas marked by soot from fires to provide light in the cave's darkness, no areas prepared for occupation, no facilities for water storage or sanitation. Instead, the intense processing and piling of defleshed animal remains resembles sacrificial deposits at Norse ritual sites elsewhere in Iceland and continental Scandinavia. The scale of these offerings appears to represent more animals than any single farm could have lost, suggesting coordination mobilization from the surrounding district. A massive stone wall, nearly 11 meters long and 4.5 meters high, blocking entry to the cave's interior, similarly required coordinated labor and skill on a scale seen nowhere else in Iceland. The scale of sacrifices and monumental construction both suggest the mobilization of labor and resources on a regional scale consistent with the action of chieftains. Radiocarbon dates suggest that these activities began shortly after the lava field in which Surtshellir formed had stopped flowing. Lava from this volcanic event covered extensive upland grazing regions and extended into recently settled lowlands. For settlers arriving from Scandinavia and the British Isles, this event – closely matching Norse mythological accounts of the destruction to be wrought by Surtur at the end of the world – must have been terrifying.
